title: How an Equipment Rental Company Cut Customer Service Time by 50% Using AI Agents | Case Study

rawLines.text: Let's walk through an example of that.
Uh you mentioned to me earlier uh work
that you've been doing with a rental
services company. I'd love to share that
story. What problem they came to you
with and then how you went about
building them an agentic solution. So so
who came to you and uh what was the
problem?
Yeah. So it's a it's a local rental
business. the they rent heavy equipment
um you know skid steers, excavators,
floor sanders, you know to a mix of
construction companies that are that are
doing things as well as the the general
public. So as you might imagine they get
tons of inquiries, right? Inquiries
around availability, inquiries around
pricing, what they what they do and
don't rent. So a lot of those calls are
coming in and distracting from the rest
of the business, right? Running running
the operations, dispatching equipment,
dealing with problems, fixing and
maintaining equipment. they run a
relatively small staff. So the the owner
of the business has to field a lot of
those calls. And his challenge was
twofold. One, he he struggled to give
the same level of customer service and
the ability to try to solve customers
problems and and get them the
information in a very customercentric
way by just taking someone off of their
post and having them answer the phones.
So he always saw a a degrading quality
if he wasn't the one doing the job. and
he then had all of the other things he
needs to do in the business suffer
because he's always taking all the phone
calls, right? So, his goal was quite
clearly just to reduce the number of
things he had to answer every day if it
was a price quote or if it was just an
answer. Do you have this if if it's
available? That was his main goal.
Therefore, he could free up his time to
deal more intimately with customers who
had problems to help his staff from
managing the the fleet of equipment and
uh and the rest of the business. So that
was the problem we set out to solve.
What we built was based off of our
framework. We we trained an agent to
know all of his pricing and all of his
pricing policies, right? So he's got
some unique ways he prices and you know
very customerfriendly way to extend a
rental and things like that as well as
delivery policies, you know, how far,
how much, etc. So we had to ch train our
agent on all of those uh you know,
different elements of his business. Um
and then it would take phone calls for
him, right? So that's that's what uh
that's what it was deployed to do. It's
mainly going to give pricing and take
bookings. Um but he he sees the
opportunity to expand that to
potentially, you know, dispatching for
dropping off equipment, picking up
equipment in the future and additional
benefits.
Yeah. How do you how do you train an
agent like that? Um, so what what sorts
of information does it have to ingest to
be able to stimulate to replicate the
experience of talking to the owner of a
business? The owner of a business who
presumably has been doing this for a
long time and is an e expert really in
his business. How how do you train that
agent? What what what sort of things do
you feed it to give it um confidence and
information to respond to questions? So
probably one of the biggest challenges
was exactly that, right? So we could get
it 70% of the way there just from data
that he had, right? He had he had data
on his website. He had, you know, his
pricing policy was clear. He had the
price per, you know, um piece of
equipment per per duration of rental. So
we could get a lot of that to ingest it
into um into answering questions just
based off of that data. And it would
give that coupled with the knowledge
that's in a large language model, right?
And of course, we had to give it
guardrail. So it wasn't making things up
or finding something on the internet and
just answering the question with
something that wasn't true and
hallucinating. So we had to narrow it
down based off of the data that we had
about his business as well as just what
the LLM can infer from knowledge. But
that only got it maybe 70% of the way
there. The other 30% was a real
difficult piece and that'll be
iterative. Um but that was extracting
all of the 20 plus years of knowledge,
right? and things he would just
intrinsically know and say on a call um
because he is who he is and what he's
done for so long and and the agent would
have no way of knowing that because it's
not written down and it's just his way
of working. Um so that was the biggest
challenge because you know he's a busy
guy and having him call and and test
during testing and training to give us
feedback is is something he had to free
up his time to do. And then the the way
to get that information out, it's not
like it was a document he just didn't
give us, right? It was knowledge and it
was in his head. So we actually came up
with a creative solution for that.
Whereas during training, he could call
and have a conversation like he was a
customer. But if the agent ever went and
did something he didn't want it to and
you know it answered a question the way
it didn't want he didn't want it to. We
actually built in kind of like a keyword
he could say which would take the agent
out of I'm a rental agent solving your
problems into I'm just listening now to
how you want me to behave and that would
give that would give him ability to
dictate to it what exactly he would say
right so now this is how I would handle
the solution or the situation in in uh
in that scenario and then we would get
that notes and our development team
could incorporate that back into the
behavior maybe that was changing the
prompt right maybe it was you know we
were getting pricing wrong or uh it had
read into something from the data and
that that happened a few times like uh
you know it doesn't rent painting
equipment doesn't rent paint sprayers or
any of those things but one of the
descriptions of a different piece of
equipment I think it was a pressure
washer had something that confused the
agent right so he started asking
questions and you know kind of broke in
and said wait a minute I don't rent this
stuff how are you getting that so we had
to figure out from what the model was
responding with from our our our rag
database as to what it was getting and
why it thought that it rented something
it didn't. And that allowed us to kind
of correct the behavior and get back on
on track. So that was a bit of an
innovative thing that we built into the
process for him in order to make it easy
for him to to help us train.
How does this integrate into his
existing business and um DNF stack?
Yeah. So a little bit of challenges
around that just because the software
that he was on from a call it a backend
product doesn't expose a lot. So we
originally just gave him a very clean
way to then take the the rental
information that the c the customer
wanted and input it. That was the first
kind of phase. The second phase is to
integrate with QuickBooks for him
because that's what he uses in the
background and they've got a more robust
API. Uh so we're going to leverage that
for a lot of the things that we can then
pull from an inventory perspective and
data and customer information. So that's
where we're pulling customer information
and um updating customer information.
We're leveraging QuickBooks from that
perspective because his other tool
didn't have it and he already has a
synchronization between those two.
Yeah. Was there any skepticism on his
part about the potential for AI and
agents to um kind of replicate him
before you began and like how how does
he feel about it now?
Yeah, there's definitely some skepticism
because he's he's again he's a very
vibrant individual, right? He's always
he's outgoing. He's very engaging,
right? So, he he wanted to really have a
digital twin of himself. And we didn't
set out to digitize his personality,
right? What we what we wanted to do was
create something that could offload the
work and do it in a very professional
way and not sound, you know, like a
robot to its end customers. So, the the
voice that we chose, right, from a
engagement perspective was part of that.
the speed with which it talks and some
of the the the ways it is engages is in
some of that. So he was a bit skeptical
at first partly because you know he is
who he is from a personality perspective
but also we just we had to temper that a
little bit and say like that we're not
trying to recreate you from a
personality perspective. We're trying to
recreate what you're doing in your
business. Um so we set expectations a
little bit from that perspective. Uh,
and then once we got the first kind of
MVP up and he could have a bit of a
conversation, just ask questions about
equipment, um, he was actually
pleasantly surprised because it's just
knowledgeable knowledgeable about what
he has and um, what it could be used for
and and whatnot. Um, and then we had to
iterate and fine-tune on the various
permutations and combinations of
equipment, right, to to make it feel
more like he would naturally engage. But
once we got it to that level, I think uh
you know, it got him to a point where he
was confident it could at least engage
uh and and take a a good portion of of
calls and answer, you know, a lot of
questions that people had. Of course, we
still need to give the customers a way
that they can escalate. He can talk to
them individually and answer questions
if if the agent can't get it. And we
anticipate that also improving over
time, right? Give it a year worth of
training and and back and forth and
it'll be better than it is on launch.
Yeah. And my understanding this is
recently deployed. So not all the
numbers are in, but previously he was
spending all his time doing customer
service related calls. What does the
kind of after state look like in terms
of what his week is like now?
Yeah, you're you're right. We're we're
early days. Um it's kind of a phased
roll out. So it's not it's not being
asked to take 100% of his workload in
the beginning here. So before Brandon
deployment, he was yeah on the phone all
the time. probably 70% of his day was on
the phone either answering questions or
taking new bookings or dealing with an
issue of of a rental. So the out of the
gate numbers were we're anticipating
tracking that towards 50% of his calls
which mainly is going to be the bookings
and pricing inquiries and do you rent
this equipment or that equipment. We
fully anticipate that he's still going
to handle customer issues where they've
had a problem, the machine can't start,
they had an accident, right? those types
of scenarios, we fully anticipate him
still engaging and that's where he's
going to spend his time on the phone.
But those lowhanging fruit from a from a
customer inquiry or booking, we
anticipate taking those calls. So,
probably about half of his total calls
and 70% of his time was on call. So,
you're talking about potentially freeing
up 35% of his time.
Yep.
And tell me a little bit about the role
of the managed service part of the
business here. um what what what what
are you doing with him on an ongoing
basis to ensure this works and scales
and delivers that value?
Yeah. So, as part of the ongoing
service, so first of all, we give him
visibility into what's going on. So, we
have a a portal that has access into
view all the calls. It analyzes
sentiment of the call. So, he he can
flag up if there was a call that was a
negative sentiment. and he can follow up
with the customer if need be or he can
listen to the call or read the
transcript and then give us feedback and
say, "Hey, this is this is behavior we
need to correct." So the service is
really to provide him the visibility
into what's going on and then work with
him to correct anything where the
behavior isn't what he wants. So then he
gets the product that he wants long
term, right? In addition to that kind of
visibility and ability to see what the
agent's doing, that human oversight, we
also have some effort for him to tune
it. So, for example, you know,
dispatching is something he he thinks it
might do in the future. Well, if if that
dispatch is as simple as saying, "Hey,
this order is in and we can read his
backend financial system and it's due
out tomorrow, right?" At the end of the
day, the agent could go through all of
the things that are due to be delivered
tomorrow and it could go and make a
phone call or a text message to the
drivers to go and say, "Hey, here's your
your schedule for the day." So building
those additional functionalities in over
time is another element of the the
managed service too. So it's going to
continue to grow and add value to his
business.

cleanText:
Let's walk through an example of that.
Uh, you mentioned to me earlier, uh, work that you've been doing with a rental services company.
I'd love to share that story.
What problem they came to you with, and then how you went about building them an agentic solution.
So, so, who came to you and, uh, what was the problem?
Yeah.
So, it's a, it's a local equipment rental business.
The, they rent heavy equipment, um, you know, skid steers, excavators, floor sanders, you know, to a mix of construction companies that are, that are doing things as well as the, the general public.
So, as you might imagine, they get tons of inquiries, right?
Inquiries around availability, inquiries around pricing, what they, what they do and don't rent.
So, a lot of those calls are coming in and distracting from the rest of the business, right?
Running, running the operations, dispatching equipment, dealing with problems, fixing and maintaining equipment.
They run a relatively small staff.
So, the, the owner of the business has to field a lot of those calls.
And his challenge was twofold.
One, he, he struggled to give the same level of customer service and the ability to try to solve customers' problems and and get them the information in a very customer-centric way by just taking someone off of their post and having them answer the phones.
So, he always saw a, a degrading quality if he wasn't the one doing the job.
And he then had all of the other things he needs to do in the business suffer because he's always taking all the phone calls, right?
So, his goal was quite clearly just to reduce the number of things he had to answer every day if it was a price quote or if it was just an answer.
Do you have this if, if it's available?
That was his main goal.
Therefore, he could free up his time to deal more intimately with customers who had problems, to help his staff from managing the the fleet of equipment and, uh, and the rest of the business.
So, that was the problem we set out to solve.
What we built was based off of our framework.
We, we trained an agent to know all of his pricing and all of his pricing policies, right?
So, he's got some unique ways he prices and, you know, a very customer-friendly way to extend a rental and things like that as well as delivery policies, you know, how far, how much, etc.
So, we had to train our agent on all of those, uh, you know, different elements of his business.
Um, and then it would take phone calls for him, right?
So, that's, that's what, uh, that's what it was deployed to do.
It's mainly going to give pricing and take bookings.
Um, but he, he sees the opportunity to expand that to potentially, you know, dispatching for dropping off equipment, picking up equipment in the future and additional benefits.
Yeah.
How do you, how do you train an agent like that?
Um, so what, what sorts of information does it have to ingest to be able to stimulate, to replicate the experience of talking to the owner of a business?
The owner of a business who presumably has been doing this for a long time and is an expert really in his business.
How, how do you train that agent?
What, what sort of things do you feed it to give it, um, confidence and information to respond to questions?
So, probably one of the biggest challenges was exactly that, right?
So, we could get it 70% of the way there just from data that he had, right?
He had, he had data on his website.
He had, you know, his pricing policy was clear.
He had the price per, you know, um, piece of equipment per, per duration of rental.
So, we could get a lot of that to ingest it into, um, into answering questions just based off of that data.
And it would give that coupled with the knowledge that's in a large language model, right?
And of course, we had to give it guardrails.
So, it wasn't making things up or finding something on the internet and just answering the question with something that wasn't true and hallucinating.
So, we had to narrow it down based off of the data that we had about his business as well as just what the LLM can infer from knowledge.
But that only got it maybe 70% of the way there.
The other 30% was a real difficult piece, and that'll be iterative.
Um, but that was extracting all of the 20-plus years of knowledge, right?
And things he would just intrinsically know and say on a call, um, because he is who he is and what he's done for so long, and, and the agent would have no way of knowing that because it's not written down and it's just his way of working.
Um, so that was the biggest challenge because, you know, he's a busy guy and having him call and and test during testing and training to give us feedback is, is something he had to free up his time to do.
And then the, the way to get that information out, it's not like it was a document he just didn't give us, right?
It was knowledge and it was in his head.
So, we actually came up with a creative solution for that.
Whereas during training, he could call and have a conversation like he was a customer.
But if the agent ever went and did something he didn't want it to, and, you know, it answered a question the way it didn't want, he didn't want it to.
We actually built in kind of like a keyword he could say which would take the agent out of "I'm a rental agent solving your problems" into "I'm just listening now to how you want me to behave," and that would give, that would give him ability to dictate to it what exactly he would say, right?
So, now this is how I would handle the solution or the situation in, in, uh, in that scenario, and then we would get that notes and our development team could incorporate that back into the behavior, maybe that was changing the prompt, right?
Maybe it was, you know, we were getting pricing wrong or, uh, it had read into something from the data and that, that happened a few times, like, uh, you know, it doesn't rent painting equipment, doesn't rent paint sprayers or any of those things, but one of the descriptions of a different piece of equipment, I think it was a pressure washer, had something that confused the agent, right?
So, he started asking questions and, you know, kind of broke in and said, "Wait a minute, I don't rent this stuff, how are you getting that?"
So, we had to figure out from what the model was responding with from our, our, our RAG database as to what it was getting and why it thought that it rented something it didn't.
And that allowed us to kind of correct the behavior and get back on, on track.
So, that was a bit of an innovative thing that we built into the process for him in order to make it easy for him to, to help us train.
How does this integrate into his existing business and, um, DNF stack?
Yeah.
So, a little bit of challenges around that just because the software that he was on from a call it a backend product doesn't expose a lot.
So, we originally just gave him a very clean way to then take the, the rental information that the c, the customer wanted and input it.
That was the first kind of phase.
The second phase is to integrate with QuickBooks for him because that's what he uses in the background and they've got a more robust API.
Uh, so we're going to leverage that for a lot of the things that we can then pull from an inventory perspective and data and customer information.
So, that's where we're pulling customer information and, um, updating customer information.
We're leveraging QuickBooks from that perspective because his other tool didn't have it and he already has a synchronization between those two.
Yeah.
Was there any skepticism on his part about the potential for AI and agents to, um, kind of replicate him before you began and like, how, how does he feel about it now?
Yeah, there's definitely some skepticism because he's, he's again, he's a very vibrant individual, right?
He's always, he's outgoing.
He's very engaging, right?
So, he, he wanted to really have a digital twin of himself.
And we didn't set out to digitize his personality, right?
What we, what we wanted to do was create something that could offload the work and do it in a very professional way and not sound, you know, like a robot to its end customers.
So, the, the voice that we chose, right, from a engagement perspective was part of that.
The speed with which it talks and some of the, the, the ways it is engages is in some of that.
So, he was a bit skeptical at first partly because, you know, he is who he is from a personality perspective, but also we just, we had to temper that a little bit and say like that we're not trying to recreate you from a personality perspective.
We're trying to recreate what you're doing in your business.
Um, so we set expectations a little bit from that perspective.
Uh, and then once we got the first kind of MVP up and he could have a bit of a conversation, just ask questions about equipment, um, he was actually pleasantly surprised because it's just knowledgeable, knowledgeable about what he has and, um, what it could be used for and and whatnot.
Um, and then we had to iterate and fine-tune on the various permutations and combinations of equipment, right, to, to make it feel more like he would naturally engage.
But once we got it to that level, I think, uh, you know, it got him to a point where he was confident it could at least engage, uh, and and take a a good portion of of calls and answer, you know, a lot of questions that people had.
Of course, we still need to give the customers a way that they can escalate.
He can talk to them individually and answer questions if, if the agent can't get it.
And we anticipate that also improving over time, right?
Give it a year worth of training and and back and forth and it'll be better than it is on launch.
Yeah.
And my understanding this is recently deployed.
So, not all the numbers are in, but previously he was spending all his time doing customer service-related calls.
What does the kind of after state look like in terms of what his week is like now?
Yeah, you're, you're right.
We're, we're early days.
Um, it's kind of a phased rollout.
So, it's not, it's not being asked to take 100% of his workload in the beginning here.
So, before deployment, he was, yeah, on the phone all the time.
Probably 70% of his day was on the phone either answering questions or taking new bookings or dealing with an issue of of a rental.
So, the out-of-the-gate numbers were, we're anticipating tracking that towards 50% of his calls, which mainly is going to be the bookings and pricing inquiries and do you rent this equipment or that equipment.
We fully anticipate that he's still going to handle customer issues where they've had a problem, the machine can't start, they had an accident, right?
Those types of scenarios, we fully anticipate him still engaging, and that's where he's going to spend his time on the phone.
But those low-hanging fruit from a, from a customer inquiry or booking, we anticipate taking those calls.
So, probably about half of his total calls and 70% of his time was on call.
So, you're talking about potentially freeing up 35% of his time.
Yep.
And tell me a little bit about the role of the managed service part of the business here.
Um, what, what, what, what are you doing with him on an ongoing basis to ensure this works and scales and delivers that value?
Yeah.
So, as part of the ongoing service, so first of all, we give him visibility into what's going on.
So, we have a, a portal that has access into view all the calls.
It analyzes sentiment of the call.
So, he, he can flag up if there was a call that was a negative sentiment, and he can follow up with the customer if need be, or he can listen to the call or read the transcript and then give us feedback and say, "Hey, this is, this is behavior we need to correct."
So, the service is really to provide him the visibility into what's going on and then work with him to correct anything where the behavior isn't what he wants.
So, then he gets the product that he wants long term, right?
In addition to that kind of visibility and ability to see what the agent's doing, that human oversight, we also have some effort for him to tune it.
So, for example, you know, dispatching is something he, he thinks it might do in the future.
Well, if, if that dispatch is as simple as saying, "Hey, this order is in and we can read his backend financial system and it's due out tomorrow, right?"
At the end of the day, the agent could go through all of the things that are due to be delivered tomorrow and it could go and make a phone call or a text message to the drivers to go and say, "Hey, here's your, your schedule for the day."
So, building those additional functionalities in over time is another element of the the managed service too.
So, it's going to continue to grow and add value to his business.
